Headline.Para: Son of actor-director Clint Eastwood, Scott Eastwood has college degree in communications

LeadPara.Para: While Clint Eastwood became a film star thanks to his work as the "man with no name" in Ennio Morricone's Spaghetti westerns, his son Scott elected to make his way as the man with his mother's name.

Determined to step out of his father's shadow, the actor, now 32, employed the name Scott Reeves in his first few films, including a pair directed by his dad - Flags Of Our Fathers (2006) and Gran Torino (2008).

TailParas.Para: Eastwood is the offspring of his father's extramarital affair with former air stewardess Jacelyn Reeves.

Eventually, however, the young actor switched back to his paternal surname. "I was 18 and I was still figuring out who I was as a man and if I could do this acting deal," he says at Corinthia Hotel in London.

"Then you start to realise no one can help you in an audition room, no matter what your last name is. They don't care. You either bomb or you don't. Then, even if you nail it, you probably still won't get the role."

From 2009 onwards, he is credited as Scott Eastwood and this is the name that stands below the title on his latest outing, the big-budget sci-fi picture Pacific Rim: Uprising, the sequel to the 2013 film from director Guillermo del Toro.

He plays the pilot of a Jaeger, a skyscraper-sized robot designed to battle enormous alien monsters. "My character pilots a machine called Gipsy Avenger," he says, "which was in the first film, though in our movie, we have a version that has been updated."

To make the piloting of these huge machines look authentic, director Steven DeKnight built a motion rig that required all the actors to permanently run on treadmills while inside the robots' command pods. They had to multitask while pretending to control the technology. "In real life, I am a pilot, so I sort of know a little bit about that," Eastwood says.
His father is a pilot, too, and flying has been a big part of the younger Eastwood's life. "I grew up flying with my dad and I grew up loving aviation."

If that seems like a rather risky activity, he says: "Driving a car is much more dangerous, with people texting and all the traffic. You are more in control of your own destiny in that sense, whereas there are a lot more factors on the ground. There are a lot of people out there who shouldn't be driving."
It is a poignant thought. Eastwood lost his girlfriend, model Jewel Brangman, to a car accident in 2014. It haunts him, he told GQ magazine in 2016.

He adds that flying keeps him grounded. "Having your identity wrapped up in film can be dangerous. That's when people maybe go nuts. I always had other things I was interested in. I was a pilot, working towards other things in life."
He is a pragmatist. Aware that making it as an actor requires luck as much as skill, he hatched a back-up plan before starting his career.

"I got a college degree in communications and I always thought if acting doesn't work, I would have another skill set," he says. "I decided I would give myself until I was 30 to make it work as an actor."
During his 20s, he followed the archetypal path of the aspiring actor, working bars and construction sites.

"I was doing these odd jobs while I was working in film and I was thinking, 'I am not making much money at this film thing, so I've got to figure out my next step.' Thenit started happening and I could make a living."

In the last few years, he has appeared in Oliver Stone's biographical thriller Snowden (2016), David Ayer's war movie Fury (2014) and comic-book romp Suicide Squad (2016). He also popped up in the eighth instalment (2017) of the Fast And Furious series.

He is developing a film about Carroll Shelby, the late American automotive designer, racing driver and entrepreneur, best known for his work on Ford's AC Cobra and Mustang marques. He is also working on a thriller with acclaimed director Nick Cassavetes.
Whatever happens with these projects, however, he will not sweat it.
Eastwood is laconic, laid-back, a bit like his dad, maybe? He smiles. "With acting, I think I fell into it. I really loved film growing up and I just said, 'Hey, let's see if I can make this work.'"
